name: Egyptian Fruit Bat
description: It is a medium-sized fruit bat with a brown to gray back, lighter belly, and yellowish collar. Its flight membranes are gray-black.
spread_note: Africa, Middle East, Asia to Pakistan
image_alt: Egyptian Fruit Bat, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 15–17 cm; tail length 6–19 mm; wingspan 60 cm; weight 80–170 g
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 4 months and give birth to 1 young
attractions: They are social mammals living in colonies ranging from 20 to several thousand individuals. They rest in caves or similar damp, dark places during the day and fly out at night to forage. They navigate not only by sight but also partially by ultrasound (echolocation), though not as precisely as true bats. They produce sounds with their tongues, detecting echoes with their ears. During breeding, partners attract each other with scent signals. Females initially carry their young on their bellies, later leaving them in a sort of 'nursery' with the offspring of other colony females.
breeding: We have kept Egyptian fruit bats since 2004, though in the mid-1950s, some passed through the zoo as 'transit' bats, with no records of their further fate.
